text:
I'm Kai Lukoff, assistant
professor at Santa Clara University . And today, I'll be
presenting on designing

to support sense
of agency for time spent on digital devices
or digital interfaces.

I'll also say that,
yeah, I'm very honored, as Michael mentioned, that this
work received the SIGCHI 2023

Outstanding Dissertation Award. And that's the basis of what
I'm going to talk about today.

So let's dive in. Computers are everywhere
in our modern environment.

And, of course, this
offers great benefits in the form of access to
information, communication,

and entertainment
at our fingertips. However, this constant
access to computers

also means that temptations
for distraction are everywhere.

And one useful way
to define temptations is, as desires that conflict
with a person's long term goals.

And people often attempt
to resist such temptations, but they often fail.

And so, for example, when people
attempt to resist temptations such as smoking, ,
drinking or shopping,

they fail around
30% of the time, according to some
experienced sampling studies.

However, the temptation with
the highest failure rate of all is media use, where people
fail about 75% of the time.

And with a computer
in our pocket nowadays, this temptation
to engage with media use is always with us
and hard to resist.

So, of course, the attention
economy and this practice of monetizing people's attention
arose over a century ago

with newspapers and radio. But the smartphone has
really dramatically enhanced

the arsenal of
attention merchants. And because of the high
rate of smartphone ownership

and its close proximity
to the user at all times, devices on our apps or apps can
really capture our attention

at any time in any place. And second apps can target
highly specific demographics.

So female MMORPG gamers
in New York City. That would have been difficult
to reach in the past.

And algorithms can, of
course, leverage this kind of granular tracking to
target content and ads that

seduce the individual user. The result is that
digital technology today

is associated with
a number of what I would call attentional harms,
that is from distractions when

driving and socializing to a
loss of productivity and sleep. And individually, the
short-term costs may seem small.

But given the amount of time
that we now spend online, I'd argue that these
costs can really

add up to undermine
our goals and values. And technology
companies often want

people to believe
that their inability to control their technology use
is due to a lack of willpower.

However, the reality is that
companies are purposefully developing technologies
that exploit

psychological vulnerabilities
to capture our attention. And so, for example, in the
popular social media game,

Farmville, there's
this pattern that when you attempt to leave
the game, you're notified that if
you don't return

within a certain period
of time, your crops are going to wither and die.

This ad on it has a-- or this
has a fake hair on it that prompts the user to click
into that particular ad.

And, of course, when you
try and brush it off, that's what happens. And so you might think of
these types of design patterns

as what could be called dark
patterns or user interfaces that are intentionally
designed to trick users

into doing things that go
against their best interests. And so far, designers have
documented dark patterns

that cause financial
harms, privacy harms, but really little about this
category of attentional harms.

And so my work
systematically examines attention-capture dark patterns.

And so given all of
these user frustrations

with a loss of control, what
should designers actually be designing for? So in my dissertation work, I
focused on the sense of agency,

the experience of control
over one's actions and their outcomes in the world. And I think of sense of
agency as a promising lens

for this work because providing
sense of agency, of course, is a principle-designed
heuristic in many HCI

guidelines. And then second,
high sense of agency is really associated with
positive technology use

outcomes. And third, I'd argue that
sense of agency matters in its own right. That is, in
self-determination theory,

it is one of the core
principles of what leads

to well-being and fulfillment. And so my investigation of
this digital environment

that fosters such
a loss of control has led me to these
three statements. And the first is that existing
screen time tools provide

insufficient control
for users to target the specific experiences
with mobile apps

that they find problematic. And second, we can identify
specific design features

within these mobile apps that
influence sense of agency. And, finally, by
redesigning mobile apps

to support a greater control
or a greater sense of agency in the right context, we can
help users align their app use

with their goals for use. OK. So let's talk a little
bit about the methods

that I employ in my research
as an HCI systems researcher. You are probably familiar
with this as an HCI group,

but I'll cover it in brief. And I think of my work in HCI
systems research as proceeding

from developing
some understanding of the user or a problem. And I might use
data-driven interviews

or experience sampling to do so. Then I'd proceed to some
phase of design or co-design,

or prototyping might
be methods there. And then on to
building, and that could be something like a mobile
app or a browser extension.

And, finally, to evaluating. And so there I might use
an experiment or a field deployment.

And so I've published across
all of these different methods at some of the
different HCI venues.

And, of course, though,
I'll say that is a very sort of linear
view of how this works.

And in practice, it
often looks something more like this, where
you circle around.

And you find that you've built
something that doesn't actually meet those user needs. And so you go back to user
understanding and so forth.

And so my talk then
also is going to go-- don't worry, follow
this linear narrative

to make things a
little bit clearer. And so the first question
that we'll take on

is, what app use makes people
feel a loss of sense of agency?

We'll go to, what design
features within apps can we change to support
sense of agency?

And then, finally, do
alternative versions of these apps support sense
of agency in the wild?

So let's dive in. So smartphone users
often describe their uses

of mobile apps as
pleasurable, but that they can distract from some
of their higher goals.

And so, for example, checking on
those dying crops in Farmville might be fun but take away
from a lunch with friends

or a challenging
programming assignment. And so one way to
understand this problem

is through the lens of
Aristotelian virtue ethics. And many smartphone
apps appear to be

excellent in this context of
providing hedonia or maximizing what feels good right now.

But as the Greek
philosopher Aristotle pointed out or proposed,
eudaimonia or growing

through challenging and
experiences that bring meaning is also a really important
component of our well-being.

And then the question
becomes, in today's era, how can we create
digital environments that support
meaningful experiences

and digital well-being? So this is work that I published
with my colleagues, Cissy Yu,

Julie Kientz, and Alexis
Hiniker at Ubicomp. And we asked, what
makes smartphone use meaningful or meaningless?

And prior research in this
area has relied primarily on user interviews in the past.

And we realized that we could
use the experience sampling method here to send the user a
short survey at the exact moment

of interest in terms of
their smartphone app use and capture some of
their in-situ data.

And so here's a diagram of the
study protocol that we used. But when our study
app detected the user

using an app on their
phone, say, Facebook, we would then
randomly detect some-- select some sort of timing
at the start of app use,

during app use, or
at the end of app use and administer an experience
sampling question which,

in our case, was,
How much do you feel like you have spent your
time on something meaningful? and have participants
rate that experience.

Yeah? Was that just a notification
you sent on the phone, and how did that work? Yeah, exactly. It was actually a pop
up inside of the app.

So-- You just use the glass
pane and drew on top of-- Exactly. Yeah, yeah.

In terms of study data, then,
we collected 86,000 samples of app use from 45
android smartphone users.

And at the end, we conducted
11 data-driven exit interviews.

And in these exit
interviews, what we did is we created these little
cuts of the users' data

during the experience or study
and presented it back to them. And we wanted to use that
so that we could really

get at the why behind
some of the ratings that they had experienced,
rather than just

getting the aggregate data. And so what type of app
use did participants

find meaningful or meaningless? Well, participants shared
that when they used apps for productivity, the experience
was mostly meaningful.

And here we found
that participants thought of productivity
broadly defined. So not just like work
productivity but also

being able to do something
socially productive. And one participant explained
that they had rated the Slack

app as a seven out of seven
for meaningfulness and said, "It's meaningful in
that way because it helps me get work done easier."

Communication was
another app use that was seen as meaningful
most of the time. And one participant
said, "I didn't

speak to my daughter
for at least five days. And then yesterday, she finally
talked to me on Facebook so that's why I put a six out
of seven for meaningfulness."

And when asked what type of
use they found less meaningful, participants often highlighted
passive social media use.

So whereas on the previous
slide a participant used Facebook for
communication and rated it high for meaningfulness,
here another participant

rated it low. And they said, "Going to
Facebook just to browse and not doing anything else,
that's pretty much meaningless."

Entertainment was also
experienced as less meaningful in general. And a participant
here shared, "I wouldn't say any time spent
on that game was meaningful.

It's just a way to entertain
myself mindlessly." So here's some of
that aggregate data.

And what we found, if we look
at meaningfulness on the y-axis and type of use
on the x-axis, we

can see that productivity
information and communication are all above a four on
our seven-point scale.

And then there's some difference
between the other two categories of entertainment
and social media,
which are both below a 3.5. And so that data-- yeah?

What delineates communication
versus social media? And that's like-- I can imagine maybe Discord
would be in a fuzzy area.

Same with Facebook Messenger. Yeah, that's a great question. I didn't cover that here. But we actually
had participants,

in addition to that earlier
experience sampling question that we had on a
seven-point scale,

self described which of these
use cases they felt their app use fell into because--

and I don't cover this here. We did know, going into
this, that participants often

use the same app for
different purposes, particularly apps like
Facebook or WeChat that

are these sprawling empires of
all kinds of different services can be used for, say,
information, communication,

entertainment, all these
kind of different use cases. So that's where we had
participants self described.

And so this told us
about the averages. But we also saw a lot
of individual variation

in the data. And we found that the same
category or type of use could sometimes be
meaningful and sometimes not.

And so, for example,
one father often played the game Candy Crush
on his phone, which he usually

rated low and meaningfulness. But in this case, he actually
rated it as a seven out of seven for meaningfulness.

And he explained, "You can't
step outside for a minute each time it gets hectic,
because it's always hectic with three
children," which I can now

identify as the father of two
children, two young children. "So I use Candy Crush to
uplift myself and relax."

And so in other
words, Candy Crush was sometimes meaningful
in this context as a relief from stressful situations.

Finally, another major theme
that came up over and over again was that participants really
felt a loss of control

that led to negative effects. And so one participant
described an example of such unconscious phone
use where they said,

"Without even realizing
it, I pulled out my phone and just started mindlessly
checking my email.

And when I put it
away, I realized, 'Oh, I feel bad for
ignoring my friends.'"

So what are some of the
takeaways from these? Yeah, go ahead. I'm wondering if meaningfulness
here is a proxy for satisfaction

or if [INAUDIBLE] if you
looked at them and [INAUDIBLE] with perceptions
of meaningfulness.

Yeah. So we didn't ask about
meaningfulness and satisfaction separately.

I kind of wish we had have
done something like that. And we do something like
that in the third study

that I'm going to present,
where we ask separately about satisfaction and
whether or not something

aligned with a person's
long-term goals. And so we'll get
to see the results on that in a few minutes.

Yeah, it's a good point. Yeah? One other detail question. You said you either
do it of when

I launch the app in the
middle of it or at the end. So what happens if I'm using
Facebook or something like that

and then I just lock the
screen and put away my phone? Does it prevent it
from locking the screen

and make me answer
the question first, or is the after only work if
I sort of swipe the app away

and I'm about to
open something else? The latter. Yeah, it only works if
you swipe the app away and about to do something else.

Then we can still send it, yeah. Excellent.  So what are some of
the takeaways, then,

from this work here? Well, first, meaning
depends upon context.

And so the same type
of app use is not a reliable indicator of
meaningfulness is what we found.

And so Candy Crush as a relief
from stressful situations.

And the same app
also was sometimes

rated as meaningful
and sometimes not. So this gets to that question
of these categories don't always

work the same way. And then, finally,
a loss of control really led to
meaningless use as well.

And so when we started
looking at this issue more,

we really realized
that this actually is central to this concern
around digital well-being.

And we found this wasn't just
because a lack of control leads to negative effects,
but also because there's,

I think, this inherent
drive to want and need to feel like you have
the ability to influence

the world around you. And so if lack of control
is a problem, then what can

designers and computer
scientists do about this?

Well, so far, I
would say concerned practitioners have
really responded with what I'd call
screen time tools, which

are now pre-installed on every
single android and iOS device. So here you can see
the Apple screen time

and Google's digital wellbeing. But one implication of my
findings on meaningfulness

is that these tools
are really too crude. They really use these
external features

that operate the same way
across all kinds of apps, such as lockout mechanisms and
timers to block access to apps.

The concern, though,
is that you're actually going to end up
indiscriminately blocking access

to meaningful
experiences for users. And that might also lead
users to abandon the tools

in the first place. So what might designers
and developers do instead?

Well, one alternative
approach is to change the design of
the internal features

inside of apps, rather than
blocking apps altogether. And so this means
identifying features

within apps, such as
recommendations, autoplay, and search to understand
which ones support

or undermine sense of agency. And so that's the
challenge that we addressed in my next research.

So now that we've gained
an understanding of some of the user needs and identified
an alternative approach

to current screen time
tools, this brings us to this question of, what
design features within apps

can we change to
support sense of agency? So this is work that I published
with my colleagues, Ulrik Lyngs,

Himanshu Zade, Vera Liao, James
Choi, Kaiyue Fan, Sean Munson, and Alexis Hiniker at CHI '21.

And we decided to
focus on YouTube and ask this question of,
what design features influence

sense of agency within
the YouTube mobile app? And we selected
YouTube as a test case

because it was one
of those apps that we found to be meaningful at
some times and not meaningful

at other times in
that first study. And it has similar
features to, of course, many other social media apps
in terms of recommendations,

autoplay, and search. And third, it has a public API
that we could, down the road,

build an alternative client
for watching YouTube videos. And so stay tuned about that.

In our first study,
we really wanted to understand which existing
features within the YouTube mobile app influence
sense of control.

And so to investigate
this question, we conducted a survey with 120
participants, all YouTube users

from the US. And our primary
question here was, what are three things
about the mobile app that

lead you to feel more
in control over how you spend your time on YouTube? And, conversely,
what are three things

about the mobile app that lead
you to feel least in control over how you spend your time?

And so then we established a
codebook with multiple coders and established our
inter-rater reliability

to analyze which features
really contributed to a sense of control in
one direction or the other.

And so here's what we found. We found this
diverging bar chart,

which is ordered in
terms of design features that are rated or mentioned
most frequently by participants.

So with recommendations being
mentioned by almost everyone down to notifications
coming up less frequently.

And the features that
primarily led participants to feel least in control
were recommendations, ads,

and autoplay. And then the ones that made
people feel most in control

were playlists, search,
subscriptions, watch history and stats, and play controls.

So let's take a look at how
recommendations led participants to feel less in control.

So one survey
participant said, "I have a hard time not looking
at the suggested videos that the algorithm picks for me.

I almost always justify
watching just one more video." And on the other
hand, let's look

at an example of a feature that
made survey participants feel a little more in control.

And that's playlists. And so one participant wrote,
"I can create playlists or queue videos in advance to limit what
I watch to a specific list,

instead of endlessly searching
around for what I want." And so as compared
to searching around,

several participants also
noted that playlists really have a clear end. And so that served
as a stopping cue

to serve as a signal for them
to finish their session of use on YouTube.

So in the second
part of this study, we really wanted
to understand what

changes to the
features of YouTube might increase sense of control. And so we conducted two
co-design activities

with YouTube users. The first was
sketching exercise. And we asked
participants to sketch

a version of the interface
of the mobile app that would make them feel
most in control and one that would make them
feel least in control.

And so you can see in the
example for less control, it's sort of plastered with
lots of different videos.

And here they wrote,
you need to scroll down to see the search bar at
the very bottom of the app. By contrast here, they
wanted to move the search bar

to the very top and
limited the recommendations to things that were already
directly interested to things

that the user had
explored previously. The second co-design
activity that we engaged with

was evaluating mockups of
different versions of YouTube that were designed from
our perspective to support

different levels of control. And so, for example, here
were three different versions of how recommendations
might work.

You could have unlimited
recommendations, which is basically
the current interface. You could have three
recommendations

and click-to-show
more videos, or you could have no recommendations. And we wanted to get feedback
on users on these interfaces.

And so one of the
interesting findings, then, was that
recommendations were

a top concern for all of
our survey participants and co-design participants. And they really
expressed frustration

with their inability to
customize their location, quantity, and content. And this was, in
particular, the case

where participants
found recommendations to be too tempting or too
good, in that they conflicted

with their other goals
at that moment in time. And so one participant said,
"When I'm tempted but no a video

is not educational, I
can hide it using the Not Interested option."

And so I think this
is pretty interesting because, in this case,
the participant is really

reappropriating this
Not Interested button for a different reason
and saying, in fact,

this is really
interesting but not now. I want to actually be watching,
say, educational content

or learning how to
cook a specific recipe. The second major finding
from our co-design

is that when participants
reviewed the different versions of their own sketches
in our mockups,

they were often
conflicted about just how much control they preferred. It depended upon the
use case, and they

preferred different levels
of control for each. So one participant here said,
"If I have a specific goal,

I know what I want, I
don't need recommendations to guide my search, I just want
to be in control of my search."

By contrast, when the
same participant did not have a specific
intention in mind,

they said, "If I just
want to watch something that gets my mind
off of things, I prefer the one
where I can choose

to show more recommendations." And so the implication, then,
is that for different use cases,

participants prefer
different levels of control. And when they had a
specific intention in mind such as watching a
tutorial to complete a Rubik's

cube, they wanted more control. And when they did not have a
specific intention in mind,

they just wanted to
relax or pass the time, then they really wanted
to lean back and let YouTube take control.

So what are some of the
implications for design here? Well, based on these
findings, one implication

would be to adapt the interface
to the specificity of the user's intention.

So, for example, when the
user has a specific intention, the design might present
a search-first interface.

On the other hand, when the
user has no specific intention, the designer might present a
recommendations-first interface.

And then switching
between these interfaces is something that
offers some potential.

So to recap, the
takeaways from our study of the features
within the YouTube app were, we first
gained this knowledge

of self-reported
sense of control when using different features. And undermining control
were recommendations, ads,

and autoplay. And supporting control
were playlists, search, and subscriptions.

The second was that
we can provide users with different levels of control
for different situations.

So then armed with this
knowledge of specific design features within apps that
affect sense of control,

can we build
alternative versions of these apps that support
sense of agency in the wild?

Well, that's what we wanted to
turn to in our final study here.

And so this is work that I
presented at the CHI conference this year, the SwitchTube study.

And we asked, can we
redesign social media apps to support digital wellbeing? And again, we used
YouTube as a test case.

So I'll start by showing a
quick demo video of the app.

So SwitchTube is an android
app, and it allows users to--

or allows us to study
design patterns that affect the user experience. And the study
participants experience

three different versions-- Explore, Focus, and Switch. And so here's Explore, which
was designed to undermine user sense of agency.

And it's similar in its features
to the official YouTube app. So you can see the home page
is recommendations-first.

It's plastered with all
kinds of recommendations. We have the search returns
entertaining results.

So you can see how
to fix a flat tire returns these
recommendations here.

And when the video
finishes, the next video starts autoplaying
automatically.

The Focus version was designed
to support user agency based on our prior findings.

And we had a
search-first home page.

And the search returned
relevant results.

And there were no video
recommendations and no autoplay when you went to watch
a particular video.

And, finally, we created
a Switch version. And that let users toggle back
and forth between the Explorer

and the Focus version.  And so we called
this Switch version

a adaptable
commitment interface, which we defined as an interface
where the user can commit

to stay focused
on their intention by blocking out distractions
but also has the option to toggle that version off.

And so we had some
competing hypotheses for how we thought this
might work in the wild.

And one was that it could
provide the best of both worlds. That is, you could choose the
scenarios in which you wanted

to use Focus mode and the others
in which you wanted to explore.

But the other was that a lot
of the way that screen time tools function is via
commitment devices.

And it could be that just being
able to easily toggle over to an Explore mode would
pose too much temptation

and be too easy to
circumvent any controls. And so then our
research questions

were, when and why do
participants toggle between Focus and Explore mode? And how does this adaptable
commitment interface

affect user experience metrics? And so that's actually
where we get a little bit

into this question of sense
of agency and satisfaction and goal alignment, which we
tried to measure separately

from each other
in the experience sampling that we
did for this study.

Our study participants, then,
were 46 US YouTube users. They were generally relatively
heavy YouTube users.

And so spent 87 minutes
per day on the service which, interestingly though,
is not that different from what

YouTube at least
reports as their median for a signed-in user
of 60 minutes per day.

And our study protocol
was such that we had the participants install the
SwitchTube app on their phone.

And then they
would be randomized into one of our three
different versions-- or two different
versions, Explore, Focus.

And, finally, we always
had Switch come at the end because we wanted
people to experience that after they'd
experienced the two versions,

they'd knew what they
were toggling in between. And then we conducted
data-driven exit interviews.

So here again, we used that
method of experience sampling, reusing the same
infrastructure that we built.

And we asked questions such
as, for this use of SwitchTube, how much did you feel
in or out of control

to measure sense of
agency, for instance?

OK. So what did we find? Well, surprisingly,
for us, participants did not spend more
time in Explorer.

There wasn't a
very significant-- there was no
significant difference in terms of time
spent in the app.

What we did find, though,
was that participants spent more time with each video
that they watched in the Focus

condition than videos in
the Explorer condition, where they were likely to
watch more different videos

for a shorter duration. Unsurprisingly,
homepage recommendations

and related videos
below the current video were a popular
source of videos when participants were in Explore.

By comparison, watching
videos from search results was popular in Focus. And in Switch, there was
some balance between the two,

suggesting that
participants use features from both of these versions.

And so in the Switch
version, when and why did participants actually toggle
between Focus and Explore mode?

Well, we analyzed data
from logs and interviews and identified four distinct
use cases that characterize

switching behavior. And I'm going to present two of
those use cases with you today. So first participants switch
to address situational needs.

And so one participant
said, "If I'm searching for something
like flat tire, I'd go with Focus because that
seems to be more educational.

Explore is definitely
more entertainment." And so, in other
words, participants did sometimes use Switch
to for the use case

that we had originally
designed for. Second, an unanticipated use
case that was interesting to us

was that participants
frequently toggled between Focus and Explore
within the same session of use.

And so one
participant here said, "I used Focus to search
for a particular video when I was done watching.

And I would turn on
Explore sometimes when I felt like looking for
recommended results underneath."

And so the way that we saw
this playing out in the data were that participants
would start in Focus mode

and make their search, for
example, for a cake decorating to avoid distractions for
their original intention.

And then they would toggle over,
once they had a cake decorating video, to the Explore mode,
see more recommendations

for cake decorating, and watch
more cake decorating videos.

And so then our second
research question here was, how does an adaptable
commitment interface affect

user experience metrics? And so we looked at
sensitive agency,

how much participants felt in
control of the use of the app. And our hypotheses based on our
previous survey and co-design

with YouTube users
were that Switch would provide the best of
both worlds, followed by Focus

and then Explore. And so our actual results
found that Switch and Focus

were both rated significantly
higher than Explore, according to this Pairwise
Wilcoxon signed-rank test

with a correction for multiple
comparisons that we conducted. And so here you can really
see the different averages

in terms of ratings between the
46 participants in our study.

And our hypotheses
about which designs would support sense of agency
here were mostly supported,

I would say. One participant
said, "In Explore, I felt like I had no control,
because it was only

the videos that were there. And Search was not
working very well. And so I was limited to what
somebody else chose for me."

OK. And so next, we
examine satisfaction.

And so this was how much
participants felt satisfied by the use of the app. And so here our hypotheses
were that Switch would again

have the highest rating. But we thought that Explorer
would actually be greater than Focus because
recommendations

would provide short-term
satisfaction that users sometimes want.

Our actual results found that
Switch was greater than Focus, and that Focus was actually
greater than Explorer.

And so what participants
told us here was that, "Switch did satisfy

Yup.  So in terms of
overall discussion,

I think the term
adaptable commitment interface can seem a paradox.

How can one commit
if one can easily switch away from that
commitment at any time?

And yet with our Switch
version, we really found that participants reported
a higher sense of agency,

satisfaction, and
goal alignment, even though that Explore
mode was only a toggle away.

And so what we think
is that Switch really worked as an adaptable
commitment interface

because it avoided triggers for
distraction in the first place. And this aligns with
an emerging consensus

in the psychological
research that people who are effective
self regulators do so by avoiding
temptations altogether,

rather than by
resisting via willpower, staring down that
cookie in the moment.

And so I think one
clear design implication is that users
would often benefit

from what you could
call a Focus mode, even within an app
such as YouTube that's

commonly regarded as a service
for entertainment but in reality does serve different use cases.

And it also advances
sense of agency as a new lens for
understanding and designing

for digital well-being, in
contrast to this screen time paradigm that I think has
been dominant thus far.

Because, ultimately, I think
what we're designing for

shouldn't be just to
limit overall time spent on the screen, but rather to
empower users to use technology

as they would like in the right
time and the right context.

And so with that,
I'd like to thank my many, many collaborators
across computer science,

engineering, design information
psychologists, and psychology, who've made this work possible.
